Text:
Here's the story:
We built a webpage - application for a client,
we tested it for months, it worked perfectly,
but since the last 2 updates, they get errors we don't,
so the only way to test them, was by keeping error logs on their server, since in our environment it still runs great.
We can send them an update, with logging added in every try block, but the code is huge,that's why i wanted to add an event to do the job
I have converted it to vb.net but still the GDI+ error occurs, the tiff file is very big (250MB)
Also look at msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/3df0c8ey(v=vs.90).aspx to create calculated datacolumns
See here msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms171897(v=vs.80).aspx for a walkthrough
Worked perfectly, thanks!
The conversion does not work at all. The reason I need the output to be hex is because I wrote it in Jave to encrypt with hex output and decrypt the hex.
What else is running or do you possibly have objects open for that database that are causing system resources to be exhausted. Does the macro perform different because the data size is large?

@GarrisonNeely I was calling that function so that the event handler executes. I have found that if you just use .Selected or .SelectedIndex than the event handler will not execute. I thought that he might want to do this since he is selecting a drop down list value in code.
item.Selected is redundant, and I'm not sure why you're calling YourDropDownList_SelectedIndexChanged() at the end.
What output do you get when you try the Hex conversion?  What does the expected output look like?  What are the differences between the two?
Should it be placed elsewhere or is there a way I can put a timer on it?

You are calling ReportProgress too often, pummeling the UI thread with updates.  It can't keep up.

Data scraping is not a nice thing to do. If you want to get data from a provider, you should ask them nicely (or use an API if provided; which is in this case not true, there is no API for the market).
Interesting, I'm gonna try it, until now I've never Know how to use selectedvalue in a properly way.

Thanks I converted into VB and it worked: Dim i As Integer = 0
        For Each listitem In DropDownList1.Items
            If DropDownList3.SelectedItem.Text = myobject.property Then
                DropDownList3.SelectedIndex = i
                Exit For
            End If
            i = i + 1
        Next

@phalanx I don't know if this will help but a read of SelectedValue from msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/… suggests that SelectedValue is chosen from the value and not the text. If you said DropDownList2.SelectedValue = "0", the text would display "-Select-". Maybe add values to the EDS and BDS list items. From the aformentioned page... "The SelectedValue property can also be used to select an item in the list control by setting it with the value of the item."
Isn't it inefficient to continue looping through items after you've found your match?
Because I don't break out of the Foreach when I find the matching ListItem, thus i is incremented to the end. I could probably optimize this with a break. :)

Well that would answer the statement of VB being like C# in this case... C# doesn't have DropDownList as its own control so it requires the use of a ComboBox with the drop-down style set to drop-down. In this case, SelectedItem is the only way to things to work for me. Thanks for the points though. :)
Why can't you just use i?
@GarrisonNeely I needed to use iSelectedIndex in order to figure out what the index was with the matching ListItem and store it.
iSelectedIndex doesn't provide any benefit here if you just exit the loop once you've matched item.Value.  This is a tad bloated.
Error: Property 'SelectedItem' is 'ReadOnly'
DropDownList.SelectedItem returns a ListItem not a custom object.
In my experience I've never had SelectedValue work.  It's just never worked for me.
Why does it not work that way? Setting the SelectedValue is the same as looping the items and setting the Selected property of the first matching item to True after ClearSelection was called.

I also want to note that your crypto is weak (ECB, no MAC, no IV) and the way you treat the key nonsensical. You don't use an appropriate salted and slow password hash, such as PBKDF2. Try dropping the .dbf extension and just use the file name (i..e, out1 and TEST).

In theory if you are using your own exception objects then they could log themselves at some point in their life cycle but I'm not sure that would be considered good practice.
That is not valid VB6 code either.  If you want to break a long statement across multiple lines then you must use an underscore _ at the end of the line.
You want the user to be able to see the items once the application is launched (started)?

There is a global place to handle exceptions globally.  If you are going to ever make a decision in some piece of code to handle an exception you have to know if the exception is going to bubble up (throw) and get handled globally or stop right there (catch) in which case you'll need to log it.

KEYEVENTF_KEYUP refers to the event of letting go of a pressed key. For example holding a key down triggers KEYEVENTF_KEYDOWN, releasing it triggers KEYEVENTF_KEYUP. However I am not sure on what KEYEVENTF_EXTENDEDKEY does

When you call that changeComputerStatus method from the other thread, are you doing so by invoking it on the UI thread, or are you just calling it directly from the background thread? (FYI, when responding to someone in particular in the comments, instead of saying "Dear so-and-so", say "@so-and-so". That way they will get a notification that you said something to them. If you don't do that, the other person won't be notified.)

It is just as easy to add a com class to an winform application as to a class library. You still have not explained your problem. What does not work? There's no point in suspending a thread forever. Why not just Abort-ing it? At least then it won't use up system resources anymore. (Or use the ThreadPool for short work items, and you won't have to think about suspending or cleaning up worker threads.)
See this 'System.Threading.EventWaitHandle' stackoverflow.com/questions/4848064/…

A note: you say so that you may "format it appropriately". I might suggest the most appropriate way to format a date is using the Culture-Specific formats of the current user. Forcing "yyyy-MM-dd" on the user might not be the best option. (depending on what you're planning to do with the string)

Have you turned on option strict and explicit in the VB compiler options? You're also hiding any other potential exceptions by only providing a catch for an IndexOutOfRangeException. @0699: I suppose that's a feasible approach. The problem with it usually becomes clear during maintenance, especially when someone other than the original coder takes over maintenance: The Tag property has no predefined, fixed meaning, it can be used for any and all purposes. So whoever will look at your code will have to guess from type casts and context what Tag might have been used for. A similar approach would be to derive from e.g. TextBox and add a properly-typed, single-purpose property whose name is somewhat more self-explanatory.
i would use the TextBox.Tag property

Of course it is - you haven't done anything to actually connect it to Excel. Declaring a variable with a type doesn't automatically make it fully functional as that type. You have to make the variable that has it "already open" available (in scope) to your Button1_Click handler and use it instead of declaring a new variable.

+1 "You are using Select Case wrong"

As I said, you could compute them at runtime by using Type.GetProperties (the answer by Dominic Kexel gives the actual detailed code to do this). If that's not possible for some reason, you'll have to go with what Steven Doggart answered.
@TimSchmelter I suppose (and the other answer demonstrates that), but honestly you are bending Select Case for something it's not really intended for at that point.  I'd prefer my answer.
+1 for giving a solution meeting the expectations of the OP perfectly (even the select case structure).
It would work in VB.NET (even if it's not best practise): Select Case True Case tempCheck.Contains("CORN")

My problem is that the contents in ExportColumnData are not computed dynamically at runtime - it's simply a hardcoded string.
Yes... It is a combo box. This isnt workin for me.

@StevenDoggart It's a more elegant way to access the properties, and with little more work, it could be a lot faster than CallByName by using Delegate.CreateDelegate (if really needed). Also, since the properties are not accessed by a string, you can be sure that each property actually exists in the Person type.

While this is an interesting example of another way of using reflection, I fail to see how this solves the type-checking concern.  You're still searching for the property by string name using reflection.
thanks it works...

@DominicKexel OK. I have edited my answer to transmit these ideas better.
You're calling the GetMethod method on an instance of the Type class. It does not matter if you got this instance by using the GetType-method or the GetType-operator. It's the same instance.
Why are you Parsing a DateTime object called "str"? it's already a DateTime.

@DominicKexel I think that "you are not using GetMethod with an instance of the class" is self-explanatory. Instead of using GetMethod directly with ClassA, I am using it with an instance of it, objA. I am open to any suggestion regarding how to write this idea better.

@DominicKexel thanks. I do agree with you on that instantiating a new ClassA sounds horrible; but if I don't do that the code does not work (by doing Type.GetType("mySpace.ClassA")). I have done some quick research to look for explanations and didn't find anything. If any answerer writes a code working without instantiating I will delete this answer right away.
Also, you are not using GetMethod with an instance of the class makes no sense, since the GetMethod method is an instance method of the type Type.

OK, I removed my downvote since your code works now and you solved two problems of the OP's code (missing BindingFlags, wrong type of the array). But creating a new instance of ClassA just to call GetType() on that instance is still terrible, because you can just use the GetType-operator.
@DominicKexel because do you agree with my other statements don't you? I am really sorry about the typo (although I would just let the answerer know via friendly comment, intead of UNFAIR -1)
